H0.text: The surface temperature causes stars to appear blue, white, yellow, and red even without the aid of a telescope.

H1.text: The distance from Earth causes the different colors of stars, which appear blue, white, yellow, and red even without a telescope.

H2.text: The distance from the Sun causes the different colors of the stars, which appear blue, white, yellow, and red even without a telescope.

H3.text: The gases that compose the star cause the different colors—blue, white, yellow, and red—seen in stars even without the aid of a telescope.

A4.text: The spectral class of a star is a short code primarily summarizing the ionization state, giving an objective measure of the photosphere's temperature.
